Details: Spoken Tutorials, a mass-market communications & learning innovation developed at IIT-Bombay, has developed a self-learning model. It takes learning from movie-industry and follows a rigorous engineering in the development process so that a learner will never have to ask any questions from an expert or coach. This approach has produced a solution that has limitless scale, almost zero cost, affords rapid deployment speed over a highly distributed and resource-constrained learner populations (in terms of language, funds, facilities, accessibility etc). Available in both online and offline mode, it has already covered 90+ IT topics (introduction to advanced programming), and in 23+ local languages to overcome barrier of English proficiency.
Key Problems Addressed: Like rest of the world, as India's economy shifts to 'digital economy' model, IT skills will be needed in almost every good-paying job. Lack of IT skills reduces employability of young people in small towns and villages, impacting nearly 300 million job-ready youth. However, there is no cost-effective way of providing such training at scale in the multiple languages prevalent in India while ensuring the required quality.
Key Solution Elements: Series of about 10-min long self-learning tutorials, which may be anywhere from 3 to 50+, depending on the solution complexity; Access to computers (preferably desktops) for practicing the learnt materials, all configured with open-source software so as to minimize cost to learn; connectivity for test administration and scoring.
Unique Value Proposition: IIT-Bombay Spoken Tutorials team
Expected Social Impact: Impact in hundreds of millions of dollars in economic benefit when the cost per student per year per IT topic of less than a penny is compared to alternatives that costs several hundred dollars per course.
Solution Traction: 8m learners across 5000+ colleges and universities and High-Schools. Prisons in Nasik. CSC (Community Service Centers) in Delhi area -- these are entreprenurial driven coaching centers.
Address: IIT Bombay Powai Mumbai Maharashtra India 400076
Target Beneficiaries: More than 300m learners across India, and nearly billions globally. Large school networks (like PM Shri Schools, Ekal, Eklavya), Education Secretaries in States.
Resources: Existing computer lab with few (just one) to 20 computers (depending upon the target class size); configured Open Source software packages for practice
Key Costs: Needs only Rs 25,000 per year per college/school/site. In that annual licensing fee, all students in that institution gets access to ALL spoken tutorials topic in all languages, testing and scoring, certificates, and support. Almost less than a penny per topic per student per year!!
Awards & Recognition: Hundreds of articles in media, Government departments, colleges and universities; Testimonials by students getting good-paying IT jobs in Global 1000 companies like Amazon, Microsoft, Accenture.

Solution: Affordable BioGas plants for rural households
Details: BioGas solution for rural / farmer households to achieve energy independence and precious savings. Fully packaged solution (with ~50% subsidy form MNRE, pre-identified supplier for digesters, step-by-step guide) to enable small farmers or rural households with just 2+ cattle to eliminate dependence on firewood or LPG, and earn income after 6-month breakeven point, by selling high-value organic fertilizer of slurry. The solution further transforms value of aging cows and animals which otherwise have diminished value in terms of milk or farming tasks.
Key Problems Addressed: Due to the high prices of LPG cylinders, farmers resort to local forests for firewood as an energy source, eventually leading to deforestation and the destruction of the environment. Additionally, naturally available cowdung is either wasted to simply contributes to landfills or problematic waste (with flies etc).
Key Solution Elements:
1)	Training in organic farming & the BioGas plant
2)	Fruit Tree Plantation
3)	Rainwater harvesting farm ponds
4)	Biogas plant - digester, pipes, connections, monitoring
Unique Value Proposition:
Unique aspect is the complete package that includes already obtained approvals for ~50% subsidies from MNRE for nationwide deployments, sourcing agreements with validated supplier, and step-by-step simple guide. It is a very cost-effective approach for multiple goals like:
a.	Uplifting farmers from poverty by multiplying their income 5X
b.	Ecologically protecting and rejuvenating the rural environment
c.	Protecting our health from side effects of pesticides and fertilizers
Expected Social Impact: To expand and serve rural populations across India. There are about 160 million farmers in India, including 80 million small farmers holding less than 1 acre land. Most of them are stuck in a vicious poverty cycle, in need of interventions that are mentioned above to improve their living conditions and alleviate poverty. Goal is to hep increase in income 5-fold compared to paddy cultivation in 2 years; Forward integration from Farm to plate; organic fruits/vegetables for cities increasing the market.
Solution Traction: 165 biogas plants have already been set up in the villages of West Bengal. Additionally, the solution has helped farmers save over Rs. 20,000 to Rs. 25,000 yearly. Expansion plans in collaboration with WHEELS to scale to other States.

Details: Newborn & Maternal Nutritional Health via Health Spoken Tutorials solution addresses very pervasive (across ALL 29 States and 9 UTs in India) early childhood malnutrition (age 0-5) with malnutrition rates of 50%+ in rural and tribal populations, using three technologies (Dr Rupal Dalal's pioneering research on proper breastfeeding techniques, IIT-Bombay's Health Spoken Tutorials platform, Cuedwell's orchestration software platform) to tackle this urgent need. Solution consists of 110+ 10-min health spoken tutorials (HST) to cover nearly 45 technical points for proper breastfeeding techniques, balanced nutritional intake for mothers as well as for supplementary and complementary feeding of infants. HSTs are used to train entire health infrastructure (CMHOs, pediatricians, nurses, ANMs, ASHA & Anganwadi workers) given the pervasive lack of awareness of proper breastfeeding techniques (which is the primary root cause of pervasive malnutrition in newborns) and balanced nutrition, using a rigorous 5-step training and capacity building methodology that ensures every health worker has mastered all the skills and is able to successfully teach the mothers for next 15-20 years.
Key Problems Addressed: Childhood malnutrition remains a major issue in virtually all parts of India in spite of the progress made in recent years. Mothers lack knowledge of proper breastfeeding, complementary feeding and looking after their own nutrition needs. ASHA & Aanganwadi workers need the right training themselves to be able to support these mothers effectively. But it has been challenging to deliver the training in an engaging and accessible way while ensuring high quality & monitoring post-training.
Key Solution Elements: HSTs (110 in nearly dozen local languages), rigorous 5-step training methodology, Cuedwell application for end-to-end learning management and impact tracking and results and real-time decision-making; learning kits
Unique Value Proposition: Learning of proper breastfeeding techniques has consistently resulted in nearly five-times weight gain in critical first 6-12 months of life, eliminating stunting / severe malnourished babies, which otherwise would remain mentally and physically underdeveloped for life.
Expected Social Impact: More than 200 million babies and mothers
Solution Traction: The rollout in Nandurbar, Maharashtra achieved phenomenal success in improving the daily weight gain of newborns from around 10 gms/day to nearly 35 gms/day, well exceeding targeted national standard. From there, the program has expanded to five other districts in Maharashtra, Gujarat, and Chattisgarh. WHEELS and IIT-B/HST team is actively deploying the initiative to the entire State of M.P. and Meghalaya. Four more large States in active negotiations.
Address: IIT Bombay Powai Spoken Tutorials Divisionb Mumbai Maharashtra India 400076
Target Beneficiaries: 200 million babies and mothers across all 28 States and 8 UTs.
Resources: IEC kits, HST, training facilities, Cuedwell application
Key Costs: Low cost and zero recurring costs, Very strong analytics digitized platform used with a train-the-trainer approach to cascade across nearly hundred thousand health workers in each large State, which then imparts proper breastfeeding techniques and nutritional intake knowledge to new mothers. Ample  Govt funds to be leveraged for training activities in a creative public-private partnership as shown in M.P. and Meghalaya.
Awards & Recognition: Numerous State and health association awards and testimonials.

Solution: RuralShores/PeopleShores - IT skills training and employment in rural areas
Details: RuralShores/PeopleShores’ borrows well-established model of IT Services Outsourcing to social impact space by creating IT Delivery Centers in impoverished tier 3/4 towns/communities that lack good-paying jobs for youth and thus forcing them to migrate to urban centers. Corp clients benefit from lower services cost, avoiding cost of hiring and retention of competitive IT talent, and CSR/Impact branding. Already scaled to 12 Centers in India under RuralShores brand, and 7 in USA under PeopelShores brand. WHEELS is supporting to help scale to hundreds more leveraging its vast network of alumni in senior leadership roles in large Corporations as well as partnerships such as CII & NASSCOM.

But high cost of wages & real estate in these cities means there is an opportunity to shift BPO work to smaller towns. Improved power and data network availability means this is increasingly possible. Without this type of model, high-school youth are forced to migrate to bigger cities, and thus hollowing out smaller towns and cities, and putting enormous pressure on bulging big cities. A massive challenge on all fronts - smaller towns, big cities, straining tax base, youth migration, income disparity etc.
Key Solution Elements: IT Delivery Services Center facility with appropriate ISO quality setup (for security, access, privacy, collaboration spaces etc), purpose-built training on IT basics to applications, and business communications; technology infrastructure; Corporate agreements and commitments for services.
Unique Value Proposition: RuralShores / PeopleShores' ImpactSourcing innovation brings very unique self-sustainable model that benefits all stakeholders -- Youth getting good-paying jobs where they grew up; host towns seeing economic transformation from these high-tech hubs with 200-300 new jobs; Corporations benefitting from cost-savings in multiple ways (services cost, hiring & retention costs) as well as powerful Social Impact / CSR branding. Solution: Samarath Initiative: Skill & vocational training with assured employment for rural youth
Details: The Raah Foundation, a partner of WHEELS, has led the effort to support these disadvantaged applicants through the program “Samarth”. Samarth is based on Raah’s existing strength and expertise in identifying gaps in the development process, offering sustainable solutions to transform the employment situation for this youth population. The program aims to provide vocational, social, and technical training for economically disadvantaged youth between the ages of 18 and 25. In addition, hard and soft skills are taught in this process, curating them towards retail, ITES, manufacturing, and customer support in banking and insurance. English and email communication, sales and marketing, typing, Tally (a popular accounting software), GST, and Microsoft Office are more skills taught through Samarth.
Key Problems Addressed:
India’s average age is around 28.4 years old, making it one of the youngest countries in the world.
The youthful demographic presents great potential for economic growth and innovation. However, about 68% of India’s youth are from rural areas with limited employment opportunities. The education system at a vast majority of these schools and colleges is not fully aligned with the corporate or job market standards, placing these young applicants at a significant disadvantage compared to their urban counterparts. As a result, India is experiencing a large pool of unemployed youth. While some live directionless lives in rural areas, those who migrate to urban areas have trouble finding employment, hence resorting to unorganized labor markets with minimal pay.
Key Solution Elements: Skills training center, disciplined selection methodology to select motivated youth, right tutors, alignment with local area employers, and partnership with CSRs for initial launch period prior to self-sustainability.
Unique Value Proposition:
The Raah Foundation has employed numerous innovative aspects to create a cost-effective and scalable model. Firstly, Samarth delivers intensive 5-week training in skills like Intuit QuickBooks, Microsoft Office, and resume-building. Additionally, they emphasize business ethics such as meeting commitments, punctuality, and maintaining professional relationships with managers and colleagues.

Another innovative aspect of Samarth is its “job assurance” initiative, which guarantees a participant's job upon program completion. By leveraging relationships with local businesses, Samarth has secured agreements to hire their trained youth, eliminating the need for interviews, and saving the companies time and money, hence the cost-effectiveness. These businesses often include banks, retailers, credit cooperatives, and microfinancing groups close to the participants’ homes, making employment accessible, known as the “placement cell”.

Lastly, the Raah Foundation has collaborated with a corporate
Expected Social Impact: Thousands of youth benefitting from long-term skills and employment; local businesses benefitting from low turnover from motivated employees that needs very little job training.
Solution Traction: With 15+ locations thriving in Nagpur, Mumbai, Pune, and more, the groundbreaking initiative of Samarth has already empowered 1,480 students by March 2024. 79% of these students have completed their training, with 77% obtaining placements and 8% advancing to higher studies. Plans in progress to expand to other States like Rajasthan in partnership with with WHEELS.

Solution: Smart Tree Plantation by Gram Samriddhi Abhiyan
Details: Gram Samriddhi Abhiyan (GSA) has developed integrated Smart Tree Plantation initiative for tripling farmer income in collaboration with regional technology institution IIT-Kharagpur whose research recommended 15-20 best trees to plant (based on soil properties, climate, rainfall patterns). This creates triple benefits: re-forestation, bio-diversity, and cash income. GSA invests in nurseries, leveraging grants and subsidies from central and State Govt programs, to distribute healthy saplings for farmers to use. Along with, farmers are given training to create a small nearby pond for water harvesting, long-term caring of the saplings and trees to ensure full 10+ years life-time value, and market linkages for proper off take and pricing. The model results in farmer often able to increase their annual income three-fold to four-fold, besides long-term environmental & ecological benefits.
Key Problems Addressed: The rural farmer generally depends on a single crop during the season and ends up working odd jobs in the other months. Crop diversification can help farmers to sustain themselves financially all through the year and reduce the risk of crop failure, increasing their income.
Key Solution Elements:
After several years of research, trials & testing Gram Samriddhi has discovered that the combination of:
1)	Training in Organic farming
2)	Fruit Tree Plantation
3)	Rainwater Harvesting farm ponds
4)	Biogas plants 
is a very cost-effective approach for multiple goals like:
a.	Uplifting farmers from poverty by multiplying their income 5X
b.	Ecologically protecting and rejuvenating the rural environment
c.	Protecting our health from side effects of pesticides and fertilizers
Unique Value Proposition: GSA promotes organic fruit tree plantation for financial security of farmers. Farmers are convinced to partially shift from paddy cultivation to organic fruit tree plantation, for which they receive technical know-how, financial support, and good quality fruit saplings. This not only brings about financial prosperity to the farmers but also ecological prosperity through biodiversity, protection of flora and fauna, enhancement of agro-forestry and conservation of natural resources- maintaining quality of soil, air and water.
Expected Social Impact: * For tens of millions of small farmers, opportunity to increase in income 5-fold compared to paddy cultivation in 2 years for farmers * Forward integration from Farm to plate * Organic fruits/vegetables for cities.
Solution Traction: In the last 4 years GSA have reached 8 blocks of several districts in south West Bengal, 900 villages, 11,000 farmers planting 4,25,000 trees.  Approx 75% of the trees survived and giving fruits. 3287 farmers were also trained creating 95 biogas plants and 600 rainwater harvesting ponds.
Address: VIP Enclave, Anand Vihar, 3 Raghunathpur, Baguiati Kolkota West Bengal India 700059
Target Beneficiaries: There are about 160 million farmers in India, including 80 million small farmers holding less than 1 acre land. Most of them are stuck in a vicious poverty cycle, in need of simple and affordable interventions like Smart Tree plantation to help alleviate their poverty.
Resources: Right selection of high-cash value fruit / vegetable tree saplings, pond for water harvesting, training for care & feed, market linkages to ensure full monetization.
Key Costs: As little as Rs 10,000 in Saplings & Rainwater Pit.
Awards & Recognition: Numerous awards and recognitions including those from State Govt and West Bengal.

Solution: Rejuvenation of Water Bodies by BJS
Details: BJS has developed a comprehensive well-documented end-to-end water-body restoration process, supported by an online portal to disseminate all the learning aids and tools and best-practices for peer NGOs to replicate the model in their districts. Matured over last ten years of extensive work in Maharashtra, this thoroughly documented and replicable approach for self-sustainable scaling - leveraging MNREGA scheme support, community contributions (for transportation of silt that comes out of dredging of the ponds / lakes / tanks -- high-value organic fertilizer), Govt or CSR funding for excavators and fuel. Creating replicable examples in 100 districts in the country.
Key Problems Addressed:
Farmers and rural communities in more than half of the country endure droughts almost every year resulting in loss of crops and livestock, falling incomes and mounting debts.

Community water bodies deteriorate in the absence of ongoing maintenance. MNREGA has resources that can potentially be used for such work but there is no mechanism to do this in an organised and ongoing way. 

Further, lack of fully scripted model and training results in restorations that are short-lived (due to improper methodology) or fail to sustain lacking community backing, commitments and structures to maintain for long-haul. 

Upfront cost of excavators is another major inhibitor, requiring creative public-private partnerships (NGO, CSRs, Govt) to overcome this huge barrier. BJS has been able to secure major support from all three stakeholders to overcome these: Tata Trusts for 100+ excavators; State Govt for fuel; local communities for labor and transportation of silt.
Key Solution Elements: Community mobilization towards unified goal of water body restoration, exact location selection, excavators to desist the waterbody, transportation of silt (high-value organic fertilizer) taken out to farms, community commitments to maintain the desalted water-body.
Unique Value Proposition: Bhartiya Jain Sanghatana (BJS)
Expected Social Impact: 100,000 villages and 20 million residents
Solution Traction: Restored more than 10,000 water bodies in Maharashtra; Now on mission to store more than a dozen water bodies in 100 districts across the country, so as to create replicable local proof-points and enabled partners to then cascade the model and accelerate the mission.
Address: Bharatiya Jain Sanghatana, Level 8, Muttha Chambers II Senapati Bapat Road Pune Maharashtra India 411016
Target Beneficiaries: All 770,000 villages and residents in India benefits from the restoration model.
Resources: Community members contributing labor for transportation of silt, Excavator machine rent and fuel costs, training, access to Govt schemes (MNREGA etc).
Key Costs: (1) Excavator rental - typically funded by CSR or Govt; (2) Fuel costs - typically funded by Govt scheme or special program or community; (3) Labor - which is typically 65% of the overall cost -- contributed by community by way of carting the excavated silt for application on their farmlands, benefiting from improved crop yield; also MNREGA scheme provides for reimbursement for labor contributions.
Awards & Recognition: Recognized by State Govt of Maharashtra, major CSRs like Tata Trust, Niti Aayog.

Details: We have worked in nearly 175 villages in Kachchh District, Gujarat in the field of Water Security. The approach was to do a thorough evaluation both on the Demand & Supply sides, do a gap analysis, identify potential interventions (Surface Water or Ground Water based), & thereafter prepare detailed Technical Specifications & Drawings, along with detailed cost estimates for the identified interventions. The next step was to raise funds for implementation of the identified interventions through individuals, corporates & also leveraging government schemes such as Sujalam Sufalam. Based on the availability of funds, we implemented a number of initiatives in multiple villages. The types of work done included : removal of invasive species, deepening & desilting of ponds, repair & raising of checkdams, recharging of defunct borewells, farm bunds & farm ponds, gauchar land development, tree plantation, & riverbed recharge tubewells. The specific solution implemented in each village depended on the soil & other geology characteristics.
Key Problems Addressed: 1. Raising funds was enormously challenging. 2. Execution of works in remote locations. 3. In certain villages, local caste/religion & political issues came in the way of moving forward.
Key Solution Elements: Geology characteristics of the local area, engineering design of structures where needed, detailed costing for each intervention, support of local community & gram panchayats, availability of funds.
Unique Value Proposition: Community centered approach, thereby facilitating long-term sustainability of the projects completed.
Expected Social Impact: Savings of over 1000 Crore Liters of water was estimated in the event of all identified interventions being implemented.
Solution Traction: One of the solutions identified, namely, Riverbed Recharge Tubewells, was subsequently taken up for replication, both by the Kachchh Zilla Parishad & Atal Bhujal Yojana. If successful, there is potential to replicate the solution across the country.

Solution: SUSTAINABLE RURAL LIVELIHOOD FOR WOMEN THROUGH VALUE ADDED PRODUCTS USING COW DUNG
Details:
India is the world’s largest producer of cattle and the second-largest producer of milk after the United States. Tamil Nadu, being one of the leading states in livestock population and dairy farming, plays a significant role in this sector. The state’s rapid economic development policies have increasingly aimed to integrate rural populations, especially women, into sustainable livelihood opportunities.
In Sindalakarai Village Panchayat, located in Thoothukudi District with a geographical area of 1,044.82 hectares, a survey conducted by the participating institute recorded a population of 1,194, of which 635 are females. The female literacy rate is 58.43%.
Agriculture is the primary occupation for women, but it does not provide a steady, year-round income. Most men in the village migrate abroad for employment, leaving women to take responsibility for the household and small-scale farming.
The main livestock of the village includes hens, goats, and cows, with around 150 native cows. Each cow produces about 10 kg of dung daily, resulting in 1,500 kg of dung every day. At present, part of this dung is used as manure, while the rest is discarded along the roadsides as waste, causing sanitation and environmental issues.
This project is designed to empower rural women in Tamil Nadu by training them to convert cow dung into value-added products such as: Eco-friendly products (cow dung doop sticks, incense sticks,  and decorative items)

Underutilized Cow Dung 1,500 kg of cow dung produced daily, but much of it is discarded on roadsides, creating waste and sanitation issues.
Lack of Awareness & Skills: Women lack training in value addition and entrepreneurship skills.
Financial Constraints: Limited access to seed capital, loans, or subsidies to start and sustain micro-enterprises.
Social & Cultural Barriers: Women face challenges in taking leadership roles due to traditional gender roles and limited decision-making power.

Eco-Friendly Products – Produce biogas, organic fertilizers, vermicompost, cow dung logs, incense sticks, and decorative items.

Scalability & Replicability – Create a model that can be replicated across rural Tamil Nadu villages with minor adjustments.

Unlike conventional agriculture, which is seasonal and uncertain, this model provides women with year-round entrepreneurial activity, enabling financial independence, improved sanitation, and environmental sustainability.

Details:
Under the supervision of Prof. Vivek Kumar (CRDT, IIT Delhi), the Unnat Bharat Abhiyan (UBA) team conducted a participatory rural exercise in 2017 in the Gaindikhata cluster of villages, Haridwar, Uttarakhand. Recognizing limited income opportunities for farmers between November and February, mushroom cultivation was introduced as a sustainable livelihood option.
With support from the local youth, district administration, and the Uttarakhand Food Processing Department, six farmers were trained in Dehradun. Using cleaned rooms in their homes, they began cultivation with compost, spawn, and poly bags provided through ONGC Foundation support. This transformation was made possible through the collective efforts of UBA, ONGC Foundation, Surabhi Foundation, district officials, and the local community, making mushroom farming a source of income, employment, and nutrition in the region.

Details: The Agro Room is a sustainable sanitation system that converts human excreta into organic manure. Designed with a three-chamber toilet setup, it separates urine, faeces, and wash water. After each use, a mix of ash, lime, and sawdust is added to eliminate odour and pathogens. Within 30–50 days, the waste decomposes into nutrient-rich night soil, offering a low-cost, eco-friendly alternative to chemical fertilizers.
Key Problems Addressed:
"Cultural hesitation around use of human waste in agriculture

Risk of pathogen contamination without proper decomposition

Awareness and behaviour change needed for adoption

Inadequate infrastructure for traditional waste collection/disposal"
Key Solution Elements:
"Three-part Toilet Pan: Front (urine), middle (faeces), and rear (cleaning water)

Separate Storage: For urine, faeces, and wash water

Odour & Pathogen Control: Use of ash, lime, sawdust; closed chamber design

Decomposition Chamber: Excreta turns into nutrient-rich manure in 30–50 days

Sustainable Reuse: Treated output used as fertilizer in agriculture
"

No need for sewer lines or septic tanks

Fully sustainable, odorless, and pathogen-free process

Closed-loop solution benefiting sanitation, agriculture, and environment

Low-cost, replicable, and easy to construct in rural areas"

Details: Cleaning of sewers and gutters often involves significant health risks. Gutters clogged with plastic and waste cause blockages and overflows. Pipe-Bot was designed to clean such clogged areas without fully opening the canal. It is a robotic system that can navigate through narrow ducts, suck out obstacles, and provide live video feedback. This solution offers a safe, efficient, and cost-effective approach to sewer cleaning, reducing the need for manual intervention and improving sanitation.
